name: Powerscourt Estate, House & Gardens
tagline: Top 3 in National Geographic's World's Top Ten Gardens
significance: One of Ireland's leading tourism attractions, ranked 3rd best garden in the world by National Geographic
foundedBy: Originally 13th-century castle by Anglo-Norman nobleman La Poer, redesigned by Richard Wingfield, 1st Viscount Powerscourt

description.short: Welcome to Powerscourt Estate, one of Ireland's leading tourism attractions featuring magnificent Powerscourt House and 47 acres of beautifully landscaped gardens, conveniently located just 30 minutes from Dublin.
description.full: Powerscourt Estate is a large country estate noted for its Palladian house and landscaped gardens, today occupying 19 hectares (47 acres) in Enniskerry, County Wicklow. The house, originally a 13th-century castle, was extensively altered during the 18th century by German architect Richard Cassels, starting in 1731 and finishing in 1741. Set amidst the stunning Wicklow landscape with views of the Great Sugar Loaf mountain, Powerscourt features a wealth of variety including perfectly manicured formal gardens, sweeping terraces, striking statues, charming ornamental lakes, secret hollows, and rambling walks. Named by National Geographic as the third finest garden across the entire globe, Powerscourt Gardens is its own world of wonder. The estate also features Ireland's highest waterfall at 121 metres (397 ft), a championship golf club, award-winning distillery, and luxury hotel. A fire in 1974 left the house as a shell until it was renovated in 1996, now housing the Avoca Terrace Cafe, retail boutiques, and exhibition spaces.
description.history: The original 13th-century castle was owned by Anglo-Norman nobleman La Poer (anglicised to 'Power'). During the 16th century it came into ownership of the Powerscourt family. In the 18th century, Richard Wingfield, 1st Viscount Powerscourt, commissioned architect Richard Cassels to extensively alter and remodel the medieval castle into a modern Palladian country house (1731-1741). King George IV visited in August 1821. In 1844, Mervyn Wingfield, 7th Viscount Powerscourt, inherited the estate and embarked on extensive renovation, creating the magnificent gardens inspired by visits to Versailles, Schonbrunn Palace near Vienna, and Schwetzingen Castle near Heidelberg. Garden development took 20 years to complete in 1880. In 1961, the estate was sold by the 9th Viscount Powerscourt to the Slazenger family, who still own it. The house was destroyed by fire on 4 November 1974 and renovated in 1996.
description.architecture: The house features severe Palladian architecture designed by Richard Cassels, with a five-bay pedimented front bookended by two circular domed towers, giving it what Sir John Vanbrugh would have called the 'castle air.' The three-storey house had at least 68 rooms. The entrance hall was 18 metres (60 ft) long and 12 metres (40 ft) wide. Main reception rooms were unusually on the first floor rather than ground floor. A mile-long avenue of beech trees leads to the house. The gardens feature the Italian Garden with dramatic sweeping terraces, Triton Lake, Japanese Garden with authentic pagoda, Walled Garden, Tower Valley with Pepperpot Tower, Pet Cemetery, statuary from across Europe, and the Bamberg Gate.
description.culturalSignificance: Powerscourt has been ranked No. 3 in National Geographic's World's Top Ten Gardens (2014) and nominated by Lonely Planet in the 'Top Ten Houses in the World' (2011). It is Ireland's first premier visitor attraction to be certified by Sustainable Travel Ireland. The estate has been used as a filming location for numerous productions including Stanley Kubrick's 'Barry Lyndon', 'The Count of Monte Cristo', 'Excalibur', and many others. Over 175,000 visitors explore the estate annually. The gardens represent the pinnacle of 19th-century landscape design in Ireland and contain the tallest tree in Ireland (Douglas Fir). The estate showcases nearly 800 years of Irish history from medieval castle to modern tourist destination.

directions.general: Conveniently located just 30 minutes from Dublin City Centre
directions.byCar: Take the N11 southbound (Wexford). At approximately 19km, take exit 7 for Bray south, Enniskerry, Powerscourt Gardens. Turn left at roundabout, over flyover and rejoin N11 heading north. Take first left for Enniskerry Village (Exit 6a). Continue to Enniskerry Village. Take the road to the left of the clock tower in the village square, continue up steep hill for 600m. Powerscourt entrance is on the right-hand side opposite church entrance.
directions.byBus: Bus services 185 and 44 take visitors to Enniskerry village. Buses run every hour. The 44 bus travels direct from City centre to Enniskerry village (approx 45 mins to 1 hour). The L15 bus connects Bray to Enniskerry. The village is a 20-minute walk from the Estate (uphill).
directions.byTrain: The nearest DART station (rail) is Bray, County Wicklow which connects the L15 bus with Dublin City Centre. The rail line runs along the coast from Malahide and Howth southwards to Greystones.
directions.parking: Ample parking for visitors in car park. Coach parking available for up to 20 coaches.

visitingInformation.averageVisitDuration: 2-3 hours for gardens, full day to include waterfall and dining
visitingInformation.adviceForVisitors: Book tickets online in advance recommended. Wear comfortable walking shoes as the estate covers 47 acres with some uphill walking. Waterfall is separate location 6km away - drive or taxi recommended. Picnics not permitted in gardens but available at waterfall. The Avoca Terrace Cafe provides excellent dining. Allow 2-3 hours minimum to explore gardens fully. Photography permitted (no commercial use or drones without permission). Dogs not permitted in gardens (except guide dogs), but dogs welcome at waterfall on leash.

highlights: 47 acres of landscaped gardens ranked 3rd best in world by National Geographic
Palladian mansion house designed by Richard Cassels (1731-1741)
Italian Garden with sweeping terraces and Triton Lake
Japanese Garden with authentic pagoda (over 100 years old)
Walled Garden with Bee Sanctuary and seasonal displays
Tower Valley with Pepperpot Tower (modelled on dining table pepper pot)
Pet Cemetery with unique 'astonishingly personal' tombstones
European statuary collection including winged horses, gods, and mythical creatures
Tallest tree in Ireland - Douglas Fir
Views of Great Sugar Loaf mountain
facilities: Multiple retail boutiques (Avoca, Neptune, Design Loft)
Wheelchair hire available (€20 refundable deposit, book in advance)
Information guides in 7 languages (English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Polish, Chinese)
Powerscourt Golf Club (East and West Championship courses)

accessibility.wheelchairAccessible: Partial - good access to gardens, shops and terrace cafe
accessibility.notes: Some areas of gardens may be inaccessible due to historic layout and heritage features. Wheelchairs available to borrow (book in advance +353 (0)1 204 6000). Disabled parking available. Drop-off point at front of house. Disabled route through gardens. Lift to ballroom on first floor. First floor shops not wheelchair accessible (steps). Disabled toilets available. Carers entitled to free entrance.
restrictions: Some historic garden areas have limited accessibility
First floor retail not accessible by wheelchair
